results.headline: Shimmying Off the Literary Mantle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Gatsby

results.summary_short: In detail and dialogue “The Great Gatsby” largely adheres faithfully to F. Scott Fitzgerald’s novel, but Baz Luhrmann has colored it lavishly with his feel for the era.

results.headline: These Two Really Need a Vacation, So Beware

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sightseers

results.summary_short: In the comedy “Sightseers,” a couple of Britons take a sometimes violent vacation.

results.headline: Freed, but Not Really Out of Prison

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Released

results.summary_short: In “Released,” drawn from an Off Broadway play, four New Yorkers recount their criminal pasts and their struggles to stay out of jail.

results.headline: A Lost Soul Packs His Fiddle and Hits the Trail

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pilgrim Song

results.summary_short: In “Pilgrim Song” a music teacher with no job, a shaky love life and a restless soul packs his fiddle and hits the trail in Kentucky.

results.headline: How Not to Impress Your Girlfriend’s Snobby Family

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Peeples

results.summary_short: In “Peeples,” directed by Tina Gordon Chism and “presented” by Tyler Perry, an upper-crust black family in Sag Harbor, N.Y., has plenty of secrets to hide.

results.headline: A Night in Louisiana Can Be Harrowing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No One Lives

results.summary_short: In “No One Lives,” a gang of hillbillies attacks a stranger, who proves not to be an easy mark.

results.headline: A Terrorist Bombing and Shadowy Men

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Java Heat

results.summary_short: In the action film “Java Heat” an American who says he’s a graduate student is injured by a bombing in Indonesia.

results.headline: A Little Song and Dance for Survival

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How Sweet it Is

results.summary_short: “How Sweet It Is,” an ode to the healing powers of musical theater, centers on a washed-up, alcoholic Broadway producer and a Mafia don to whom he owes money.

results.headline: After the Breakup, the Revenge Movie
results.display_title: He's Way More Famous Than You

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of He's Way More Famous Than You

results.summary_short: In “He’s Way More Famous Than You” a fallen starlet is dumped by her filmmaker boyfriend.

results.headline: A Mad Man Someone Should Hire
results.display_title: And Now a Word From Our Sponsor

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of And Now a Word From Our Sponsor

results.summary_short: In “And Now a Word From Our Sponsor,” an ad executive is reduced to speaking only in slogans.

results.headline: Civilization Comes Crashing Down

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aftershock

results.summary_short: In “Aftershock” an earthquake in Chile sets the stage for a pell-mell disaster movie that dispatches its characters with the efficiency of a horror film.

results.headline: A Spiritual and Musical Journey
results.display_title: One Track Heart: The Story of Krishna Das

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Track Heart: The Story of Krishna Das

results.summary_short: “One Track Heart: The Story of Krishna Das” is a documentary about this singer of the Indian devotional music called kirtan.

results.headline: Adult Head Games, Focused on a Child

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What Maisie Knew

results.summary_short: “What Maisie Knew,” an adaptation of the Henry James short novel, is about a young girl caught in a custody battle between her mother and father.

results.headline: Don’t Bring Daddy to School for Vocation Day

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Iceman

results.summary_short: In “The Iceman” Michael Shannon plays Richard Kuklinski, a notorious contract killer who is as cold as his nickname suggests.

results.headline: Sex and Sadness After a Failed Revolt

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Something in the Air

results.summary_short: Olivier Assayas’s “Something in the Air” looks at the aftermath of a promising revolutionary energy that surged through France in 1968.

results.headline: A Feminist’s Beer Ads and Safaris

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fragments of Kubelka

results.summary_short: The documentary “Fragments of Kubelka” explores the life and art of an experimental filmmaker.

results.headline: For a Nerdy Teacher, It’s Time to Man Up

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wuss

results.summary_short: “Wuss,” directed by Clay Liford, focuses on a timid teacher seeking revenge after he is beaten up by school bullies.

results.headline: Lessons in Expatriate Filmmaking

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unmade in China

results.summary_short: The documentary “Unmade in China” shows the setbacks and power grabs that befell the writer and filmmaker Gil Kofman while he was directing the thriller “Case Sensitive” in China.

results.headline: Search for Identity Reaches an Impasse

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Turtle Hill, Brooklyn

results.summary_short: In “Turtle Hill, Brooklyn,” a gay couple are unsettled emotionally, as are many of their party guests, for varied reasons.

results.headline: Horrors Come Along for the Trip

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Happy House

results.summary_short: In “The Happy House,” a young urban couple take a vacation in the country, with the ensuing terrors becoming symbolic of everything that’s wrong between them.
